children.name: sb who thinks he/she is very clever annoyingly
smart aleck
children.definition: /ˈsmɑːʳt ˌælk/  informal someone, especially a young person, who annoys you because they say funny or intelligent things in a rude way:
examples: người làm ra vẻ thông minh , tinh khôn , ngông nghênh [danh từ đếm được ] nói 1 cách không chính thức là 1 ai đó, đặc biệt là người trẻ, người làm phiền bạn bởi vì họ nói điều gì hài hước hay thông minh bằng 1 cách thô lỗ
▪ Glover was different to the rest of us. The son of university people. A smart aleck.
Glover khác với chúng tôi . Con trai của người học đại học. 1 đứa ngông nghênh
▪ Some smart aleck at the back of the room kept standing up and asking awkward questions.
1 vài đứa tỏ ra vẻ thông minh đứng ở cuối phòng và hỏi những câu hỏi rắc rối
smart-aleck[adjective]
ngông nghênh, tỏ ra vẻ thông minh [tính từ ]
▪ I’m not going to let some smart-aleck kid make a fool out of me.
Tôi không để những đứa trẻ ngông nghênh biến tôi thành 1 trò hề cho người khác xem.

children.name: know-it-all
children.definition: alsoknow-allBritish /ˈnəʊ ɪt ɔːl, ˈnəʊ ɔːl/  spokensomeonewho annoys you because they always think they know the correct answers, know a lot about something etc:
examples: người làm như thê cái gì cũng biết [danh từ đếm được ] nói 1 ai đó làm phiền bạn bởi vì họ luôn nghĩ họ biết câu trả lời chính xác, biết nhiều về thứ gì đó vâng vâng
▪ OK, if you’re such a know-it-all, you try and do it, then.
Ok , nếu bạn là người cái gì cũng biết , hãy cố gắng và làm nó
▪ I just wish he’d stop being such a know-all all the time.
Tôi chỉ ước anh ấy dừng ngay việc tự cho mình biết hết mọi thứ mọi lúc

children.name: smart-ass/wise guy
children.definition: /ˈsmɑːʳt æs, ˈwaɪz gaɪ/  American informal someone who annoys you because they make jokes or give answers in a rude but funny way:
examples: người khôn ngoan , hóm hỉnh [danh từ đếm được ] Người Mĩ 1 cách không chính thức là 1 ai đó làm phiền bạn bởi vì họ đùa giỡn hay trả lời câu hỏi 1 cách thô lỗ nhưng vui nhônk
▪ OK, smart-ass! If I want an answer from you I’ll ask for it.
Ok , kẻ hóm hỉnh ! Nếu tôi muốn câu hỏi từ bạn tôi sẽ hỏi bạn về điều đó
smart-ass[adjective only before noun]
rất thông minh [tính từ chỉ đứng trước danh từ ]
▪ Some smart-ass college kid started making fun of her accent.
1 số sinh viên đại học rất thông minh đã bắt đầu lấy giọng của cô ấy ra làm trò cười

children.name: be too clever by half
children.definition: /biː tuː ˌklevəʳ baɪ ˈhɑːfǁ-ˈhæf/  British informal use this about someone who uses their intelligence in a way that annoys other people, and will probably get into trouble at some time in the future:
examples: quá ư là thông minh (mỉa mai) [cụm động từ ] người anh nói 1 cách không chính thức là sử dụng cái này về 1 ai đó sử dụng trí thông minh của họ để làm phiền người khác , và có thể sẽ gặp rắc rối tại thời điểm nào đó trong tương lai
▪ Phil’s good at thinking up excuses for his behaviour - he’s too clever by half.
Phil rất giỏi trong việc nghĩ ra lời bào chữa cho những hành vi của mình - Anh ta quá ư là thông minh

children.name: not very clever
children.definition: not very/too bright/intelligent/clever/smart sb whois not very bright/intelligent/clever/smartis unable to learn and understand things quickly and easily:
examples: Sometimes I think Sheila just isn’t very bright.
Saja may be handsome, but he’s not too smart
Franco works hard but he isn’t really very intelligent.
He treated me like a young and not very clever child.

children.name: idiot
children.definition: sb who is stupid
examples: Whenever I phone the bank I get through to some idiot who sounds about twelve years old.
Stop treating me like an idiot -- I can count you know!

children.name: stupid
children.definition: showing a lack of good sense or good judgment
examples: She talks to us as if we’re completely stupid
Poor Larry’s too stupid to realize when you’re making fun of him.
It’s only stupid people who believe in all that astrology mumbo-jumbo.
Register : Stupidis very frequent in spoken English, but in written English people usually prefer to use more a formal alternative, such asfoolishorunwise, which sounds more polite.

children.name: bimbo
children.definition: informal a young woman who is attractive but not very intelligent, especially one who spends time with rich and famous people: gái lẳng lơ
examples: Backstage, Paul was surrounded by bimbos in short skirts just waiting for him to notice them.
She plays an apparent bimbo who manages to outwit her boss.
a blonde bimbo
He went out with a succession of blonde bimbos.

children.name: dumb
children.definition: especially US, spoken not at all intelligent:
examples: The athletic guys were seen as ‘cute but dumb’.
You’re so dumb, Clarissa!
If we look dumb enough, someone’s bound to come and help us out.
‘What is it?’ I asked,playing dumb(= pretending to be stupid ).
She’s nodumb blonde(= a pretty woman with blonde hair who seems stupid).
a bunch of dumb kids

children.name: airhead
children.definition: informal a very stupid person:
examples: He treats his women staff as if they’re all airheads.
Then some overpaid TV airhead starts telling us how wonderful her producer is.

children.name: thick
children.definition: British informal not at all intelligent:
examples: He’s a nice boy, but he’s a bit thick, isn’t he?
Not wishing to appear thick, but what exactly are you doing?
as thick as two short planksvery stupid
Some of the students they let in these days are as thick as two short planks.

children.name: moron
children.definition: offensive a very stupid person:
examples: What do you think I am, a complete moron?
Most media companies assume members of the general public are morons.
moronic[adj]
There was one member of the newsgroup who kept emailing me with moronic questions.

children.name: brainless
children.definition: informal completely stupid : không não
examples: My sister’s latest boyfriend is pretty brainless; it’s impossible to have a conversation with him.
‘You brainless scum!’ he shouted after the departing boys.

children.name: dim
children.definition: /dɪm/  informal unintelligent and very slow to learn: lù đù
examples: ▪ She’s not the brightest kid in the class -- in fact, she’s quite dim.
▪ I’m playing a guy who’s well-meaning but kind of dim.

children.name: gormless
children.definition: UK informal very stupid - use this especially to describe sb who looks stupid or who never has their own ideas: ngu xuẩn
examples: He just sat there with his mouth open looking really gormless
a grinning, gormless boy

children.name: unintelligent
children.definition: formal not as intelligent as most people:
examples: ▪ It would be a mistake to assume that all football players are unintelligent.
▪ He may not be as bright as his sister, but he’s far from unintelligent.

children.name: quick to understand or make decisions
quick
children.definition: intelligent and able to understand things quickly: lanh lợi, nhạy bén
examples: ▪ Some children in the class are quicker than others.
▪ She’s very quick and able -- seems to pick things up in no time.
quick at (doing) sth
Craig was always quick at maths, but he had trouble with reading and writing.
She was quickatunderstandingwhat we wanted her to do.

children.name: quick-witted
children.definition: able to understand things quickly and to answer people in an intelligent way : nhanh trí
examples: ▪ John was always so quick-witted that I used to think he would have made a good secret agent.
▪ Throughout a lifetime of public service, he proved himself a quick-witted negotiator.

children.name: wise
children.definition: a wise person makes good decisions and gives good advice, because they have a lot of experience of life - use this especially about older people: khôn ngoan
examples: a wise old man
She was a wise old woman, and we all valued her advice
Burton didn’t like what he was hearing, but he was wise enough to keep his thoughts to himself.
older and wiser
At the time I thought he was wonderful, but I’molder and wisernow.
As a manager, Sanfordwas wise in the ways of(= knew a lot about )company politics.
wisely[adv] C1
The Queen ruled her people wisely for more than 60 years.

children.name: be quick on the uptake
children.definition: spoken informal sb who is quick on the uptake learns new things and understands a situation very quickly: sáng dạ , nhanh hiểu, “sự hấp thu”
examples: ▪ You’re very quick on the uptake! How did you guess?
▪ We’re looking for new staff - people who are neat, enthusiastic and quick on the uptake.

children.name: good at learning, thinking understanding ideas
clever
children.definition: especially UK/smartespecially US B1  good at learning and understanding things quickly, and at thinking how to solve problems: thông minh
examples: ▪ He’s a smart kid who works hard and is focused on what he wants to do.
▪ My sister was always much cleverer than me at school.
it is clever/smart of sth
▪ That was very clever of you, How did you do that?
it is clever/smart of sb to do sth
▪ Dick’s had a bad injury, and it’s probably smart of him not to play sports for a while.

children.name: intelligent
children.definition: learning, and understanding ideas: thông minh
examples: Mark was an intelligent, ambitious young man, with a great future in front of him.
Some scientists claim that dolphins are more intelligent than humans.
highly intelligent
‘We’re looking for highly intelligent young people, with a genuine interest in their subject,’ a university spokesman said.

children.name: bright
children.definition: intelligent and likely to be successful - use this especially aboutchildrenandyoungpeople: sáng dạ, thông minh
examples: Even as a small child, it was obvious that Bobby was very bright.
When I first met her she was a bright young lawyer fresh out of law school.
best and brightest
Companies want to prevent their best and brightest employees from being headhunted by rival organizations.

children.name: brainy
children.definition: informal very intelligent and especially good at studying: rất thông minh
examples: At school Karen was always one of the brainy ones.
Why don’t you ask Tom to help you with your homework -- he’s incredibly brainy.

children.name: have a good mind
children.definition: to be intelligent and able to think about things clearly, understand things quickly, and solve problems well:
examples: ▪ Sean’s teachers told him that he had a good mind and the ability to be an excellent student.

children.name: have a high IQ
children.definition: to be intelligent according to what you score on a special test:
examples: có chỉ số IQ cao
▪ Both the twins have a high IQ of around 150.
▪ MENSA is an organization for people with high IQs.

children.name: gifted
children.definition: a child who is gifted is much more intelligent and quicker at learning than most other children: có năng khiếu
examples: In the past, gifted children have not always been given appropriate educational support.
Bloomsbury House is a special school for girls and boys who are exceptionally gifted.

children.name: brilliant
children.definition: /ˈbrɪljənt/  a brilliant scientist, student, lawyer etc is one who is extremely intelligent and extremely successful at what they do:lỗi lạc , tài ba
examples: ▪ The brilliant physicist Paul Dirac first put forward this theory back in 1990.
▪ a brilliant historian

children.name: genius
children.definition: sbwith a very high level of intelligence, which only a few people have, especially someone who has original and important ideas: thiên tài, bậc kì tài
examples: ▪ Perot was a wonderful businessman and a genius in his own way.
mathematical/musical/artistic etc genius
▪ Einstein was probably the greatest mathematical genius of all time.

children.name: clever at dealing with people or situations
shrewd
children.definition: a shrewd person is good at deciding what people, situations etc are really like, so that it isdifficult to deceive them- use this especially about people who aresuccessfulinbusiness:lanh lợi, sắc sảo
examples: ▪ As a manager, Watson is both shrewd and tough.
▪ Are you a shrewd businessman, quick to see an opportunity or a bargain?
▪ Sachs was a shrewd judge of character, and chose his staff well.
shrewdly[adverb]
▪ They shrewdly invested in copper just as the price started to rise.

children.name: astute
children.definition: sb who is astute easily understands why people behave in a particular way, why a situation is happening etc, without anyone having to tell them: tinh khôn
examples: ▪ Morgan was surprised at how astute she was. ‘How did you know that?’ he asked.
▪ The scale of the riots seemed to surprise even the most astute commentators.
financially/politically etc astute
▪ The President’s wife is often politically astute, ambitious and very influential in White House policy decisions.
astutely[adverb]
▪ As one observer astutely pointed out, ‘A week is a long time in politics.’

children.name: canny
children.definition: sb who is canny is very clever, especially in business, so that it is difficult to deceive them and they are able to take advantage of other people: lanh lợi
examples: ▪ Pete Chambers is a canny fellow. Not one to miss an opportunity.
▪ She’s far too canny to keep her money in this country. She’s got it safely hidden away in Switzerland, I expect.

children.name: resourceful
children.definition: clever at finding ways to deal with problems or difficult situations, using whatever material, information etc that is available to you: tháo vát, khéo xoay xở
examples: We can influence our children’s development by encouraging them to be resourceful when they play.
Keen competition in the arts, crafts and trade made the Greeks an inventive and resourceful people.
She's a very resourceful manager.

children.name: streetwise
children.definition: sb who is streetwise has a lot of experience of life in big cities, so they know what to do in difficult or dangerous situations:
examples: ▪ He seemed very streetwise for a kid who had just left school.
▪ Zachar is a streetwise guy from New York, a gambler who grew up playing the horses at Belmont Park.

children.name: be no fool
children.definition: / be nobody’s fool informal to be very difficult to trick or deceive because you have a lot of experience or knowledge of people: không ngốc, ngu dại
examples: Katherine could look after herself and she was nobody’s fool when it came to money.

children.name: clever
children.definition: especially British /smartespecially American B1  intelligent in a practical way, and able to use your intelligence to get advantages for yourself: thông minh
examples: ▪ Ben Gurion was a cool, calculating and clever politician.
▪ They won the case by being clever and hiring influential lawyers to help them.
▪ She was smart and knew how to get men to give her whatever she wanted.
clever at doing sth
▪ Doug’s always been clever at finding the best deals available.
cleverly[adverb]
▪ Mum cleverly pretended that she hadn’t heard what he’d said.

children.name: sb who behaves in a stupid way
idiot
children.definition: sb who does sth very stupid or embarrassing:
examples: You lost the tickets? How could you be such an idiot?
Some idiot in a fast car is trying to overtake.
She was an idiot to drink so much on an empty stomach.
[ as form of address ]You stupid idiot - that's a month's work you've lost!
Some idiot left the tap running in the bathroom and there's water everywhere.

children.name: wally
children.definition: /ˈwɒliǁˈwɑː-/  British informal sb who behaves in a stupid and annoying way
examples: Look at those wallies jumping around and pulling faces behind the TV reporter.
You look like a right wally in that hat.

children.name: jerk
children.definition: especially American someone who is a little stupid and annoying, and who does not care if they upset or hurt other people:
examples: ▪ Some jerk just drove right into the back of my car
.▪ I liked the job, but the manager was a jerk.
▪ Ow! You jerk, that hurt!
total/real jerk
▪ She seems to always end up in a relationship with some total jerk.

children.name: goof
children.definition: /goof ball/guːf, ˈguːf bɔːl/  American informal sb who is stupid and embarrassing:
examples: ▪ He’s such a goof. I don’t know what she sees in him.
▪ He always acts like a real goof after a couple of glasses of wine.
Oh Mike’s okay, he’s just a bit of a goof ball.

children.name: dope
children.definition: American informal sb who is stupid and does not think about what they say or do:
examples: ▪ I’m sorry I was such a dope last night.
▪ Oh you dope, you bought the wrong one.

children.name: dork
children.definition: especially US, informal sb who you think is stupid and strange because they behave strangely or wear strange clothes:
examples: I look like a real dork in this uniform.
Millions of listeners heard him call his production assistant a ‘dork’ live on air.

children.name: fool
children.definition: sb who has done sth stupid:
examples: What a foolshe had been to think that he would stay.
Like a fool, I accepted straight away.
Yousilly old fool!
make a fool of yourselfdo sth that makes you seem very stupid
It’s increasingly common for the losers to go out kicking and screaming, and generally making fools of themselves.
[ as form of address ]You fool, you've missed your chance!
[ + to infinitive ]He's a fooltothink she still loves him.
He's foolenough tothink she still loves him.
My foolof a(= silly) husband has gone out and taken my keys!
If you believe that, you’re a bigger fool than I thought.
Anyone who tells you any different is either a fool or a liar.
